title: Patent Office Seeks Help From AI
text:
The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office is expanding its use of artificial intelligence to tackle steadily growing patent applications, including an influx of AI-related filings.

The patent office last month posted a job opening for a tech expert to guide the use of artificial intelligence and other AI-enabled capabilities across the agency, reporting to its chief information officer, Jamie Holcombe.

“The time is ripe,” said Andrei Iancu, the agency’s director. “Our need is high and technology has advanced, so this is a good time to take advantage of these new tools to help our examiners,” Mr. Iancu said.

The agency’s AI expert will advise the CIO on state-of-the-art implementations of smart tools in its internal business units, while creating a road map for using AI, including machine learning, to drive efficiencies in both the patent and trademark examination process, Mr. Iancu said.

The goal is to speed up the overall process, he said, in part by automating aspects of the research performed by staff examiners and supervisors, reducing mundane administrative tasks and cutting costs by eking out efficiencies.

The agency received about 643,000 patent applications last year, inching down from 2017, but up from about 619,000 in 2014, according to the agency. AI-related applications grew to about 3,800 in 2018 from roughly 3,200 in 2017 and about 1,900 in 2014. Figures for 2019 haven’t been released.

Applications last year included smart software and other tools related to machine learning, neural networks and AI-enabled learning methods, according to the agency. Most are being filed by large companies, with roughly 40% coming from applicants based in California, agency data shows.

The patent office is grappling with the broader issue of whether an AI system can be recognized as the inventor of a product.

U.S. Chief Technology Officer Michael Kratsios, speaking at a recent AI forum in Washington, said the country has roughly 2,000 AI companies, including 17 of 32 global AI startups valued at more than $1 billion.

Large companies are acquiring AI firms “because the technology has reached a state where it can provide significant benefits,” said Michael McLaughlin, a research analyst at the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a technology policy group. The number of such acquisitions has increased every year since 2012, he said, growing to 191 last year from 17 in 2012—with U.S. firms accounting for 68% of global AI acquisitions.

The increases reflect an upswing in world-wide AI spending, according to estimates by technology research company International Data Corp. Led by software, global spending on AI is projected to hit $35.8 billion this year, up 44% from 2018, and is expected to more than double to $79.2 billion by 2022, IDC estimates.

The U.S. federal government’s fiscal-year budget for 2020 requested $973.5 million for unclassified, nondefense AI R&D. In addition, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, which is part of the Defense Department, last year announced a $2 billion initiative to develop AI technologies.

Ritu Jyoti, IDC’s global lead for AI, said the technology offers large organizations—including the patent office—an opportunity to improve operational efficiencies, boost customer services, cut costs and drive revenue.

All that activity is boosting demand for skilled AI workers. Mr. Iancu said the patent office has received many job applications from a diverse group of candidates. He said the agency’s strategy is to pitch its core mission of supporting innovation.

For the right person at the right point in their career, he added, “we can offer a unique opportunity to make a real, long-lasting difference for the country and our innovation economy.”

The agency expects to fill the post by next week.
